references.A43JOH01USGP: Johnson, D.H. 1943. Systematic review of the chipmunks (genus Eutamias) of California. University of California Publications in Zoology, 48:63-148.
references.A36BAI01USGP: Bailey, V. 1936. The mammals of life zones in Oregon. North American Fauna, 55:1-416.
references.A76STA01USGP: States, J.B. 1976. Local adaptations in chipmunk (Eutamias amoenus) populations and evolutionary potential at species' borders. Ecological Monographs, 46:221-256.
references.B46HAL01USGP: Hall, Raymond E. 1946. Mammals of Nevada University of California Press, Berkely and Los Angeles, California.
references.B63STO01USGP: Storer, T.I., and R.L. Usinger 1963. Sierra Nevada natural history. University of California Press, Berkeley, CA.
references.W03CAL01USGP: California Department of Fish and Game. 2003. California Wildlife Habitat Relationships System. http://www.dfg.ca.gov/whdab/html/cawildlife.html.
references.B98VER01USGP: Verts, B.J., and L. Carraway. 1998. Land Mammals of Oregon. University of California Press, Berkeley, CA.
references.R99WIL02SEGP: Wilson, D.E. and S. Ruff. 1999. The Smithsonian book of North American mammals. Washington, DC, Smithsonian Inst. Press. 750 p.
references.B92SUT01USGP: Sutton, D. A. 1992. Tamias amoenus, The American Society of Mammalogists Mammalian Species No. 390: 1-8.
references.B95HAL01USGP: Hall, E. R. 1995. Mammals of Nevada. University of Nevada Press: Las Vegas, Nevada. 710 pp.
references.R80VER01USGP: Verner, J. and A. Boss. 1980. California wildlife and their habitats: western Sierra Nevada. For. Serv. Gen. Tech. Rep. PSW37. U.S. Dep. Agric. Berkeley, CA.

habitat_description:
Southwest:
This species “occupies a much broader range of habitat types than T. senex, T. speciosus, or T. quadrimaculatus, with which it is sympatric” (Sutton 1992).  “...usually found in brush-covered areas where snowberry (Symphoricarpos), chinquapin (Castanopsis), mountain mahogany (Cercocarpus), service berry (Amelanchier), antelope brush (Purshia), current (Ribes), and buckbrush (Ceanothus) are found.....Such shrub areas are interspersed with a a variety of grasses and herbs as well as open conifer stands” (Sutton 1992). “The places where this species enters the state all have some yellow pines (or Jeffrey pines in the vicinity of Lake Tahoe) as well as other plants characteristic of the Transition Life Zone” (Hall 1946).  “Cercocarpus ledifolius is greater cover in the “Yellow Pine” belt than is yellow pine” itself; chart shows species above the pinyon-juniper belt (Hall 1946). In Sierra Nevada of NV and CA, “in conifer forests around chaparral, logs, and rocks” (Storer and Usinger 1963). In California,  “... open stands of most coniferous forest habitats, montane hardwood, montane hardwood-conifer, pinyon-juniper, and many great Basin shrub habitats (CDFG 2003). Also in California, “Widespread in all pine and fir forests from ponderosa pine to lodgepole pine...... most abundant in ponderosa pine forests (Verner and Boss 1980). Elevation range “in California extends from about 975 m to timberline at about 2,900 m (Johnson, 1943)” (Sutton 1992). In Sierra Nevada, “4400-9400 feet” (1341-2865 m) (Storer and Usinger 1963). Wilson and Ruff (1999) quote an elevation range from about 950 m to 2800 m.

Northwest:
In central Oregon, Verts and Carraway (1998) describe T. amoenus habitat as "open juniper-ponderosa pine forests with understories of big sagebrush and rabbit-brush; ponderosa pine with scattered lodgepole pine forest with understories of bitter-brush; and open ponderosa pine forests with dense patches of piine regeneration and some replacement of ponderosa pine by Douglas-fir and with understories of tobacco-brush and manzanita. Both in this region [central OR] and elsewhere in the state, ponderosa pine seems to be the common factor in habitats occupied by the species (Bailey 1936). Nevertheless, individual T. amoenus occasionally range short distances from the forest edge into shrub-steppe communities; at one locality, 30% of captures in shrub-stepped were >130 m from the forest edge, but at another site, noe was as far as 130 m (States 1976)".
